displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And meanwhile as I get all the scans and all that and get a chance to look at your bone scans. Patient: Do you want me to step out or stay here? Doctor: Uh stay here. If Dr. L____ wants you moved to a different room of his I’ll let you know. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Patient: Sounds good. Thank you. Doctor: Okay and today your Lupron and all that you’ve been getting right with Dr. K____. Okay so that’s updated. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Okay so Patient: Good. Doctor: Okay so there is no new areas. The lung, liver, everything is completely clear. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: The lymph nodes, you know the only change we see is one lymph node in the abdomen that has gone from six millimeter to eight millimeter which I think even if I measured it an hour apart I might come up with –

Patient: Yes. Um hum. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: Well, so. Doctor: Alright. You know, we can, there are other options there for you. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Are you able to have an erection at all with the pills? Patient: Uh, you know, I’ve been having, you know, just like something happening, and- Doctor: But it’s not effective enough that you can have sex with it? Is that what you’re saying? Patient: Uh, well, I have, but, you know, it’s like I wanted to get better, you know, so. Doctor: Okay. So you’re able to have an erection enough that you can penetrate the vagina? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So you want to get better?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: because weirdly enough it’s IV so it’s not a pill like what you’ve been on with all of your prior treatments. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: Anything else we’re missing? The other thing that’s hard about Xofigo though is that sometimes it doesn’t make the PSA go down. In fact, two-thirds of the people the PSA rises up and you’re like is this stuff in me, hello, are these guys pocketing it or what’s going on and it’s just something that happens bone wise that sometimes you just see almost the worsening of the PSA and yours is already going up so I bring that up so it won’t be like oh, my god, she’s ah, doesn’t she not know it’s higher. Patient: The conference we went to I learned about that. Doctor: Yes, you did. Patient: So that, that was well worth being there just for that. Doctor: Oh, I’m so glad. Patient: So I’m well aware of that. Doctor: Awesome. Patient: I told my kids that. I said, oh man, that’s, yeah, so I understand that. Doctor: Yeah, so you know it’s something we consider but just so you know we don’t combine the two, right.

Patient: I, yeah, I, um, for now on, I’m trying to do them here. I don’t want to --- Doctor: Are we doin’ it on the same day or are you coming in early or? Family Member: We should – they want you to come in early so they can have something – Patient: The appointment for the twenty-fifth, she wanted me to come in a few days earlier. The nurse was saying --- Family Member: A week early. Or Doctor: The same would be true for me in April, if you could do it early? Patient: Yeah, yeah. I will. Doctor: You could do it the same day, but then we don’t – Patient: No, I will. Doctor: But I just have to tell you about aliens, and I’ve got nothing else to talk to you about. Patient: Well, yeah, I know. I’ll get my daughter over here. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may, I don’t think we have an opening at Hospital B but that’s one of the sites that we collaborate with, and I think they had interest in opening it, and so we can check in to see whether they have that open. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But that would be clearly if we say I’m doing chemotherapy, do I want to do something more on top of it, so that would be one option. Experimentally we have two treatments, uh one based on the fact that your ARV7 is positive. We have an experimental study where we give everyone immune therapy, a doublet. That is a combination of two drugs that are approved in melanoma, soon to be approved in kidney cancer that can turn on your immune system to attack your cancer. It doesn’t work all that well so far in prostate cancer, maybe fifteen percent of people may get a benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh some data that said people who are on Enzalutamide stay on Enzalutamide and get these drugs uh may have a higher response rate, and that’s what we are testing. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have done this already in fifteen men and I think three people benefited for a period of time, relatively short. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But still benefited and so they did not have Enzalutamide or the Xtandi, so we’re doing fifteen more who have Xtandi uh and seeing whether or not it’s a higher response because of that.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And if it’s time we do it. You know? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If it’s like absolutely the same, then we’re just going to hang out. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, kind of play around with pills and see if we can get it down. Family Member: Oh, okay. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But I need to be assured as you guys do also. Family Member: Right. Doctor: That there’s nothing new or that these guys all of a sudden didn’t wake up and go, yeah, well, we were sleeping. Family Member: Right. Doctor: All those lymph nodes and now we’re awake. And we would know if we’re awake because it would be bigger or if it was new. Like, wait a minute.

Family Member: Multi-grain, right, okay multi-grain. Okay, so that’s it. Now I know this is early and he’s feeling fine, but somebody brought it up and I want to ask you. When he starts radiation, chemotherapy is it possible to get the medical marijuana or how is that to happen? Patient: I never used my form, so we Family Member: And so we need to know in what form you know he should take Doctor: I hope he doesn’t need marijuana have an Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It’s only people who you know just have nausea that just can’t be controlled by medicines - Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then we would use marijuana. Family Member: Okay, that’s what I was told - Family Member: Just to stop vomiting and that so she mentioned that her son um had cancer. And so she mentioned that and I said I will ask. Doctor: So any other questions? Family Member: No.

Family Member: Your urine. Patient: Yeah. Okay. No problem. Doctor: But you’re not leaking or anything? Patient: No. Doctor: How many times you up at night to pee? Patient: Hum, once or twice at night. Doctor: Okay. Have you been to the hospital since I saw you? Patient: No. Doctor: So you feel like you’re holding your own, getting worse, feeling better? Patient: Yeah, hum, I’m holding my own. Doctor: Any falls? Patient: No.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. And um if anything changes on the scan, we’ll let you know. Patient: You’ll call me, and- Doctor: But you need your injection. Right? Today? Patient: Yes. Um hum. But in three months, I’ll get another CAT scan? Patient: Maybe not? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. When do you get a bone scan, yearly? Doctor: Yeah. Depending on how you do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. So today all you had was a CAT scan or did you have both? Patient: Yes. Yes. No. Just a scan. Doctor: Oh. So you didn’t go to D___, then?

Patient: Yeah, there is – Doctor: African Americans Patient: Yes, very much so. I talked to her about all of it because— Doctor: Who’s going to look at these films, I don’t know. But someone’s going to look at them, and there’s science going to be done. I don’t know what it is, but – Patient: If there, uh, Doctor: How many times I blinked at you or something. I’m not sure what the – Patient: In part of the work that I do, she was --- I do race disability Doctor: Yeah, you told me that, yeah. Patient: So, they were interested in what, how I answered questions. Anyway. Doctor: Alright. You did a good job. You get an A. Family Member: Alright. Doctor: I don’t even know if this things still working. Family Member: We’re all movie, movie stars now.

Patient: It was a man that invented that transfusion and some other stuff they invented. What ever happened to him? Doctor: You know it’s not a transfusion, right? Patient: Right. Doctor: Yeah. So a transfusion means- Patient: I mean, you know, he, you know- Doctor: Infusion. Patient: Infusion. Yes. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: He invented that infusion. Doctor: Yes. Patient: So whatever happened to him? Doctor: I’m not sure if any one man invented it. So it’s a company called, D___, so it’s several scientists that have figured that out. I have no idea what’s happened to them but the company, you know, is still alive and well, and, they, we give the stuff all the time to people. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: No. Doctor: What about bending it? No? Patient: Um no. Family Member: xxx].I’ll tell you what I did. I, I, still play paddleball which is like racquetball. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And occasionally I’ll swing I’ll get a zinger down here and that’s from back there you know. And the neurologist told me to quit playing. Doctor: Yeah I was gonna ask you did you check with the neurosurgeon if it’s safe to do it. Patient: Oh yeah. Nah, it’s not safe. Doctor: It doesn’t sound safe. Patient: No. Doctor: Oh you’re just preferring to not get … Patient: Well I got a…

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And with time, like more months, like up to September. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: In September if that that – if nothing happens, then we can go to another ah step Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: in treating the sexual function. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Injections into the penis. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Uh but that’s I don’t know if I gave you a book about that or not. Patient: Uh no, no you just you know you discussed the options. Doctor: Well I’ll get you some literature about that, but injections would be the next step.

Family Member: Gotcha. Doctor: That’s the problem. Patient: I’m not eating less. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I do feel that I’m eating better… Um… Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Yeah because you got a week off. Patient: Pardon? Family Member: Oh no. (laughs) Patient: Oh no, no. My, my uh… My appetite has never been affected by this medication. Doctor: Okay. Alright. Patient: I do notice one thing while I was off. I I can feel the difference in the energy level. Doctor: Yeah. Which is probably not helping me having you drink more because then you’re just more active and on the go.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -to say that there is absolutely has the same effect as chemotherapy on PSA or it has the effect like Xofigo. So that’s something we’ll find out but I think if everything else is lining up that you’re doing well on this treatment. I don’t think we should just make a decision and jump off the treatment is the PSA is going up. Patient: Oh. Family Member: That makes sense. And what if his bone scan is positive? The one he just had. Is the… Doctor: Yeah so if it shows progression, then I think we have to look – change gears to a different treatment and that’s where all those options come in whether to do chemotherapy, whether to do Xofigo or whether to do that new hormonal pill. So any of those are equally good options. Family Member: Okay. Patient: I see. Family Member 2: So you don’t have any more questions K___? Family Member: I don’t think so. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah I know, she said that. Family Member 2: We’re glad that she was able to come. Doctor: Yeah, no that’s wonderful. Yeah it’s important to… What do you think or are you ready to bail from this treatment? Patient: Yeah.
